content:
I made some UI mockups of showing timestamp in messages in local timezone. Any suggestions?
pasted image
@Brock Whittaker @Tim Abbott

cool! I like the clock icon and the light background shading. Some minor comments:

  • I would put a radius of 2-4 pixels or so (whatever we do for the @-mentions)
  • Maybe remove the year unless it is in a future year?
  • How about something like Thu, July 6, 11am? So abbreviated day, lowercase AM, and no space before it? I feel like more compact is generally better.
  • For "not a good time", can we just show whatever they typed (without the clock, highlighting, etc)?
For points 1,2, and 3, I'll do that. And i typed !time(not a good time) to get that output... so, its exactly as you say. Plus, on hover, you get a tooltip saying "Could not parse timestamp."
pasted image
I think the clock will look more obviously like a clock if you move the hands a bit, to, say, 4:00.
I think the standard is to have the hands pointing at 10:10
I think its one of the [:clock6: :clock6:] emojis. I can't find a :clock1010:, but there's :clock4: or :clock10:.
Let's use :clock4 for now, but I think we should actually have one of our designers make a new image that won't be confused with an emoji.
(or feel free to do so yourself, of course)
Yes its the :clock6: emoji scaled down. I'll change it to :clock4: for now. I'm not good at photo editing and design at all. :/

Looking good! I'd also suggest a bit of space between the clock and the "Thu", and removing the space before the am.
Also, what do folks think of the th? I feel like it will be tough to internationalize/localize, so I'm tempted to remove it.
Should I create a clock icon pointed at 4?
@Rishi Gupta I'm not sure what you mean by the "th".
I think we should start with just using an emoji (or font-awesome icon) to keep things simple
